title: Meet Max, Harvey and Rose
text: Max is full of ideas, Harvey loves facts, and Rose encourages everyone. Today they’re starting a tiny garden of microgreens at home. Microgreens are baby plants you harvest young for fresh flavour and nutrients.

title: What are microgreens?
text: Microgreens are seeds grown for 7–14 days until the first small leaves appear. You snip them above the soil and enjoy them fresh. They are simple to grow indoors on a bright windowsill.

title: What’s in the kit?
text: 2 half coconut shell planters (empty); 10 coco-coir pellets; fine mist spray bottle; 3 seed tins (choose from radish, broccoli, pea, sunflower, kale, red cabbage, rocket, spring onion); wooden spoon for seeds and spreading coir; plant labels; Microgreen Explorer’s Guide; bee-friendly seeded paper; quest/certificate.

title: Safety first
text: Wash hands and tools. Supervise children with water and scissors. Keep the growing area tidy and dry around the shells. Check seed allergies: brassicas, sunflower, pea/legume, and alliums.

title: Prepare the coco coir
text: Place pellets in a clean bowl. Add water a little at a time until they fluff up. Use the wooden spoon to spread coir evenly in your coconut shell, about 1–2 cm deep. The coir should be damp, not soggy.

title: Sowing your seeds
text: Sprinkle seeds in a single, even layer—no big piles. Press them gently so they touch the coir. Mist lightly so all seeds are damp. Label your shells so you remember what’s what.

title: Dark stage (2–3 days)
text: Cover the shell loosely (a clean plate or card) to create a cosy ‘dark stage’. This helps roots grab hold. Peek daily and mist if the surface looks dry. Keep it slightly damp.

title: Into the light
text: When you see sprouts pushing up, remove the cover and give bright, indirect light. A sunny windowsill works; avoid strong midday sun. Mist to keep the coir damp, not wet.

title: Watering basics
text: Mist once or twice a day depending on room warmth. If leaves look droopy or coir feels dry, add a few extra mists. If it looks soggy or smells off, ease up and let it air.

title: Roots or mould?
text: Root hairs look like tiny white fuzz along stems—normal and friendly. Fuzzy patches that spread across the surface and smell unpleasant may be mould. Improve airflow, avoid over-watering, and clean tools.

title: Leggy shoots
text: If stems are long and bendy with small leaves, they need more light. Move to a brighter spot (indirect light) and rotate the shell daily so shoots grow upright.

title: Too wet or smelly?
text: If the surface looks shiny or there’s a musty smell, you’re over-misting. Give the shell a day with fewer sprays and better airflow. Harvest what looks fresh and start a new tray if needed.

title: When to harvest
text: Most microgreens are ready 7–14 days after sowing. Look for the first pair of true leaves and sturdy stems. Use clean scissors to snip just above the coir.

title: After cutting
text: Rinse gently in cold water and pat dry with a clean towel. Enjoy fresh for the best taste and crunch. Store leftovers in a lidded container lined with a dry kitchen towel.

title: Easy ways to eat microgreens
text: Sprinkle on cheese sandwiches, omelettes, baked potatoes, soups, and salads. Add them at the end so they stay crisp. Try a small handful on toast with hummus or cream cheese.

title: Nutrition — Broccoli microgreens
text: Broccoli microgreens provide vitamin C, K, A and folate and contain sulforaphane. Vitamin C contributes to normal immune function and protection of cells from oxidative stress. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting and maintenance of normal bones.

title: Nutrition — Kale microgreens
text: Kale microgreens are rich in vitamin K and A, with vitamin C too. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting and bone maintenance. Vitamin A contributes to normal vision and skin.

title: Nutrition — Red cabbage microgreens
text: Red cabbage microgreens provide vitamin C and colourful plant pigments (anthocyanins). Vitamin C contributes to normal immune function and protection of cells from oxidative stress.

title: Nutrition — Radish microgreens
text: Radish microgreens have vitamin C and peppery glucosinolates. Vitamin C contributes to normal immune function and reduction of tiredness and fatigue.

title: Nutrition — Pea shoots
text: Pea shoots provide vitamin K, C and folate. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting and bone maintenance; folate contributes to normal psychological function and reduction of tiredness and fatigue.

title: Nutrition — Sunflower shoots
text: Sunflower shoots provide vitamin E and plant protein. Vitamin E contributes to the protection of cells from oxidative stress.

title: Nutrition — Rocket (arugula)
text: Rocket microgreens are peppery and contain vitamin K and naturally occurring nitrates. Vitamin K contributes to normal blood clotting; nitrates can support normal blood flow during exercise via nitric oxide pathways.

title: Nutrition — Spring onion microgreens
text: Spring onion microgreens bring bright flavour and contain plant compounds such as quercetin. Use as a garnish on savoury dishes. (General educational note only.)

title: Allergens
text: Check seeds and family sensitivities: brassicas (broccoli, kale, radish, red cabbage, rocket), sunflower, pea/legume, alliums (onion). If unsure, ask a grown-up or health professional.

title: Tidying up
text: Compost used coir if you can. Wash the coconut shells, spray bottle, and scissors with warm soapy water. Dry well before storing for next time.

title: Bee-friendly paper (planting)
text: Moisten the bee paper and lay it on a shallow bed of coir or potting soil. Keep it damp and in bright light. Some seeds may sprout indoors; most will bloom outdoors in spring.

title: Planting bee paper outdoors
text: If it’s autumn or winter, you can plant the paper in a pot or a patch and let the seeds sleep through winter, waking in spring. In colder spells, keep it dry and plant in spring.

title: Explorer Quest & certificate
text: Complete simple tasks: label your shells; take a photo of day 3, day 7, and harvest day; try microgreens on a new food. Tick each step and collect your Mini Green Grower certificate.

title: FAQ — My seeds didn’t sprout
text: Check dates and keep the coir evenly damp. Make sure seeds are pressed to the surface and had 2–3 days in the dark stage. Try a warmer spot away from cold drafts.

title: FAQ — Windowsill too hot or cold?
text: Microgreens like steady warmth and light. Avoid radiators and cold draughts. Bright, indirect light works best; rotate the shells daily for even growth.

title: Glossary
text: Coco coir: soft fibre from coconuts used as a growing medium. Dark stage: first 2–3 days covered so roots anchor. True leaves: the next set of leaves after the seed leaves.
